an3.122:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three kinds of sagacity.

an3.122:1.3.eng: Sagacity of body, speech, and mind.

an3.122:1.4.eng: And what is sagacity of body?

an3.122:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, abrahmacariyā paṭivirato hoti.
an3.122:1.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or have sex.

an3.122:2.1.eng: And what is sagacity of speech?

an3.122:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti.
an3.122:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

an3.122:3.1.eng: And what is sagacity of mind?

an3.122:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an3.122:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an3.122:3.4.eng: These are the three kinds of sagacity.

an3.122:4.1.eng: A sage in body, a sage in speech,

an3.122:4.4.eng: has given up everything, they say.”

an3.123:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kusinārāyaṃ viharati baliharaṇe vanasaṇḍe.
an3.123:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kusinārā, in the Forest of Offerings.

an3.123:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an3.123:2.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati.
an3.123:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.

an3.123:2.2.pli: Tamenaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā upasaṅkamitvā svātanāya bhattena nimanteti.
an3.123:2.2.eng: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for the next day’s meal.

an3.123:2.3.eng: The mendicant accepts if they want.

an3.123:2.4.pli: So tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena tassa gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamati; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdati.
an3.123:2.4.eng: When the night has passed, they robe up in the morning, take their bowl and robe, and approach that householder’s home, where they sit on the seat spread out.

an3.123:2.5.pli: Tamenaṃ so gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeti sampavāreti.
an3.123:2.5.eng: The householder or their child serves and satisfies them with their own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

an3.123:3.2.pli: ‘sādhu vata myāyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeti sampavāretī’ti.
an3.123:3.2.eng: ‘It’s so good that this householder serves me with delicious fresh and cooked foods.’

an3.123:3.4.pli: ‘aho vata māyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā āyatimpi evarūpena paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeyya sampavāreyyā’ti.
an3.123:3.4.eng: ‘I really hope this householder serves me with delicious fresh and cooked foods in the future, too.’

an3.123:3.5.pli: So taṃ piṇḍapātaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhosanno anādīnavadassāvī anissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati.
an3.123:3.5.eng: They eat that food tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.

an3.123:3.6.pli: So tattha kāmavitakkampi vitakketi, byāpādavitakkampi vitakketi, vihiṃsāvitakkampi vitakketi.
an3.123:3.6.eng: They think about it with sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts.

an3.123:3.7.pli: Evarūpassāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno dinnaṃ na mahapphalanti vadāmi.
an3.123:3.7.eng: A gift to such a mendicant is not very fruitful, I say.

an3.123:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu aññataraṃ gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upanissāya viharati.
an3.123:4.1.eng: Take another case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.

an3.123:4.2.pli: Tamenaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā upasaṅkamitvā svātanāya bhattena nimanteti.
an3.123:4.2.eng: A householder or their child approaches and invites them for the next day’s meal.

an3.123:4.3.eng: The mendicant accepts if they want.

an3.123:4.4.pli: So tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena tassa gahapatissa vā gahapatiputtassa vā nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamati; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdati.
an3.123:4.4.eng: When the night has passed, they robe up in the morning, take their bowl and robe, and approach that householder’s home, where they sit on the seat spread out.

an3.123:4.5.pli: Tamenaṃ so gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeti sampavāreti.
an3.123:4.5.eng: The householder or their child serves and satisfies them with their own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

an3.123:5.2.pli: ‘sādhu vata myāyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeti sampavāretī’ti.
an3.123:5.2.eng: ‘It’s so good that the householder or their child serves and satisfies me with their own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.’

an3.123:5.4.pli: ‘aho vata māyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā āyatimpi evarūpena paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappeyya sampavāreyyā’ti.
an3.123:5.4.eng: ‘I really hope this householder serves me with delicious fresh and cooked foods in the future, too.’

an3.123:5.5.pli: So taṃ piṇḍapātaṃ agathito amucchito anajjhosanno ādīnavadassāvī nissaraṇapañño paribhuñjati.
an3.123:5.5.eng: They eat that almsfood untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.

an3.123:5.6.pli: So tattha nekkhammavitakkampi vitakketi, abyāpādavitakkampi vitakketi, avihiṃsāvitakkampi vitakketi.
an3.123:5.6.eng: They think about it with thoughts of renunciation, good will, or harmlessness.

an3.123:5.7.pli: Evarūpassāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno dinnaṃ mahapphalanti vadāmi.
an3.123:5.7.eng: A gift to such a mendicant is very fruitful, I say.

an3.124:1.1.pli: “Yassaṃ, bhikkhave, disāyaṃ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti, manasi kātumpi me esā, bhikkhave, disā na phāsu hoti, pageva gantuṃ.
an3.124:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I’m not even comfortable thinking about a place where mendicants fight—quarreling and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words—let alone going there.

an3.124:1.2.eng: I come to a conclusion about them:

an3.124:1.3.pli: ‘addhā te āyasmanto tayo dhamme pajahiṃsu, tayo dhamme bahulamakaṃsu.
an3.124:1.3.eng: ‘Clearly those venerables have given up three things and cultivated three things.’

an3.124:1.4.eng: What three things have they given up?

an3.124:1.5.eng: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness.

an3.124:1.7.eng: What three things have they cultivated?

an3.124:1.10.pli: Yassaṃ, bhikkhave, disāyaṃ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti, manasi kātumpi me esā, bhikkhave, disā na phāsu hoti, pageva gantuṃ.

an3.124:1.11.eng: I come to a conclusion about them:

an3.124:1.12.pli: ‘addhā te āyasmanto ime tayo dhamme pajahiṃsu, ime tayo dhamme bahulamakaṃsu’.
an3.124:1.12.eng: ‘Clearly those venerables have given up three things and cultivated three things.’

an3.124:2.1.pli: Yassaṃ pana, bhikkhave, disāyaṃ bhikkhū samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharanti, gantumpi me esā, bhikkhave, disā phāsu hoti, pageva manasi kātuṃ.
an3.124:2.1.eng: I feel comfortable going to a place where the mendicants live in harmony—appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes—let alone thinking about it.

an3.124:2.2.eng: I come to a conclusion about them:

an3.124:2.3.pli: ‘addhā te āyasmanto tayo dhamme pajahiṃsu, tayo dhamme bahulamakaṃsu.
an3.124:2.3.eng: ‘Clearly those venerables have given up three things and cultivated three things.’

an3.124:2.4.eng: What three things have they given up?

an3.124:2.7.eng: What three things have they cultivated?

an3.124:2.8.eng: Thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness. …

an3.124:2.10.pli: Yassaṃ, bhikkhave, disāyaṃ bhikkhū samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṃ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharanti, gantumpi me esā, bhikkhave, disā phāsu hoti, pageva manasi kātuṃ.

an3.124:2.11.eng: I come to a conclusion about them:

an3.124:2.12.pli: ‘addhā te āyasmanto ime tayo dhamme pajahiṃsu, ime tayo dhamme bahulamakaṃsū’”ti.
an3.124:2.12.eng: ‘Clearly those venerables have given up three things and cultivated three things.’”

an3.125:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati gotamake cetiye.
an3.125:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Gotamaka Shrine.

an3.125:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an3.125:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I teach based on direct knowledge, not without direct knowledge.

an3.125:2.2.pli: Sanidānāhaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desemi, no anidānaṃ.
an3.125:2.2.eng: I teach with reasons, not without them.

an3.125:2.3.pli: Sappāṭihāriyāhaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammaṃ desemi, no appāṭihāriyaṃ.
an3.125:2.3.eng: I teach with a demonstrable basis, not without it.

an3.125:2.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, abhiññāya dhammaṃ desayato no anabhiññāya, sanidānaṃ dhammaṃ desayato no anidānaṃ, sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desayato no appāṭihāriyaṃ, karaṇīyo ovādo, karaṇīyā anusāsanī.
an3.125:2.4.eng: Since this is so, you should follow my advice and instruction.

an3.125:2.5.pli: Alañca pana vo, bhikkhave, tuṭṭhiyā, alaṃ attamanatāya, alaṃ somanassāya:
an3.125:2.5.eng: This is enough for you to feel joyful, delighted, and happy:

an3.125:2.6.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha! The teaching is well explained! The Saṅgha is practicing well!’”

an3.125:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an3.125:3.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
an3.125:3.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

an3.125:3.3.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne sahassī lokadhātu akampitthāti.
an3.125:3.3.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the thousandfold galaxy shook.

an3.126:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ caramāno yena kapilavatthu tadavasari.
an3.126:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans when he arrived at Kapilavatthu.

an3.126:1.2.pli: Assosi kho mahānāmo sakko: “bhagavā kira kapilavatthuṃ anuppatto”ti.
an3.126:1.2.eng: Mahānāma the Sakyan heard that he had arrived.

an3.126:1.3.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an3.126:1.3.eng: He went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side. The Buddha said to him,

an3.126:2.1.pli: “Gaccha, mahānāma, kapilavatthusmiṃ, tathārūpaṃ āvasathaṃ jāna yatthajja mayaṃ ekarattiṃ vihareyyāmā”ti.
an3.126:2.1.eng: “Go into Kapilavatthu, Mahānāma, and check if there’s a suitable guest house where I can spend the night.”

an3.126:2.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavato paṭissutvā kapilavatthuṃ pavisitvā kevalakappaṃ kapilavatthuṃ anvāhiṇḍanto nāddasa kapilavatthusmiṃ tathārūpaṃ āvasathaṃ yatthajja bhagavā ekarattiṃ vihareyya.
an3.126:2.2.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Mahānāma. He returned to Kapilavatthu and searched all over the city, but he couldn’t see a suitable guest house for the Buddha to spend the night.

an3.126:3.1.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.126:3.1.eng: Then Mahānāma went up to the Buddha, and said to him,

an3.126:3.2.pli: “natthi, bhante, kapilavatthusmiṃ tathārūpo āvasatho yatthajja bhagavā ekarattiṃ vihareyya.
an3.126:3.2.eng: “Sir, there’s no suitable guest house in Kapilavatthu for you to spend the night.

an3.126:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ, bhante, bharaṇḍu kālāmo bhagavato purāṇasabrahmacārī.
an3.126:3.3.eng: But there is this Bharaṇḍu the Kālāma, who used to be the Buddha’s spiritual companion.

an3.126:3.4.eng: Why don’t you spend the night at his hermitage?”

an3.126:3.5.eng: “Go, Mahānāma, and set out a mat.”

an3.126:3.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavato paṭissutvā yena bharaṇḍussa kālāmassa assamo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā santharaṃ paññāpetvā udakaṃ ṭhapetvā pādānaṃ dhovanāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.126:3.6.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Mahānāma. He went to Bharaṇḍu’s hermitage, where he set out a mat, and got foot-washing water ready. Then he went back to the Buddha and said to him,

an3.126:3.7.pli: “santhato, bhante, santhāro, udakaṃ ṭhapitaṃ pādānaṃ dhovanāya.
an3.126:3.7.eng: “The mat and foot-washing water are set out.

an3.126:3.8.eng: Please, sir, go at your convenience.”

an3.126:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena bharaṇḍussa kālāmassa assamo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an3.126:4.1.eng: Then the Buddha went to Bharaṇḍu’s hermitage, sat down on the seat spread out,

an3.126:4.4.eng: “It’s too late to pay homage to the Buddha today.

an3.126:4.6.pli: Sve dānāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ payirupāsissāmī”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
an3.126:4.6.eng: Tomorrow I’ll pay homage to the Buddha.” He bowed to the Buddha and respectfully circled him, keeping him on his right, then he left.

an3.126:5.1.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko tassā rattiyā accayena yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an3.126:5.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

an3.126:5.2.pli: “tayo khome, mahānāma, satthāro santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an3.126:5.2.eng: “Mahānāma, there are these three teachers found in the world.

an3.126:5.4.pli: Idha, mahānāma, ekacco satthā kāmānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti;
an3.126:5.4.eng: One teacher advocates the complete understanding of sensual pleasures,

an3.126:5.5.pli: na rūpānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti, na vedanānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti.
an3.126:5.5.eng: but not of forms or feelings.

an3.126:5.6.pli: Idha pana, mahānāma, ekacco satthā kāmānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti, rūpānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti;
an3.126:5.6.eng: One teacher advocates the complete understanding of sensual pleasures and forms,

an3.126:5.8.pli: Idha pana, mahānāma, ekacco satthā kāmānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti, rūpānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti, vedanānaṃ pariññaṃ paññāpeti.
an3.126:5.8.eng: One teacher advocates the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, forms, and feelings.

an3.126:5.9.pli: Ime kho, mahānāma, tayo satthāro santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an3.126:5.9.eng: These are the three teachers found in the world.

an3.126:5.10.pli: Imesaṃ, mahānāma, tiṇṇaṃ satthārānaṃ ekā niṭṭhā udāhu puthu niṭṭhā”ti?
an3.126:5.10.eng: Do these three teachers have the same goal or different goals?”

an3.126:6.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bharaṇḍu kālāmo mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ etadavoca:
an3.126:6.1.eng: When he said this, Bharaṇḍu said to Mahānāma,

an3.126:6.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ etadavoca:

an3.126:6.5.pli: Dutiyampi kho bharaṇḍu kālāmo mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ etadavoca:
an3.126:6.5.eng: For a second time, Bharaṇḍu said,

an3.126:6.7.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ etadavoca:

an3.126:6.9.pli: Tatiyampi kho bharaṇḍu kālāmo mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ etadavoca:
an3.126:6.9.eng: For a third time, Bharaṇḍu said,

an3.126:6.11.pli: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā mahānāmaṃ sakkaṃ etadavoca:

an3.126:7.2.pli: “mahesakkhassa vatamhi mahānāmassa sakkassa sammukhā samaṇena gotamena yāvatatiyaṃ apasādito.
an3.126:7.2.eng: “The Buddha has rebuked me three times in front of this illustrious Mahānāma.

an3.126:7.4.pli: Atha kho bharaṇḍu kālāmo kapilavatthumhā pakkāmi.
an3.126:7.4.eng: Then Bharaṇḍu the Kālāma left Kapilavatthu,

an3.126:7.5.pli: Yaṃ kapilavatthumhā pakkāmi tathā pakkantova ahosi na puna paccāgacchīti.

an3.127:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an3.127:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an3.127:1.2.pli: Atha kho hatthako devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā:
an3.127:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Hatthaka, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha. Thinking,

an3.127:1.3.pli: “bhagavato purato ṭhassāmī”ti osīdatimeva saṃsīdatimeva, na sakkoti saṇṭhātuṃ.
an3.127:1.3.eng: “I will stand before the Buddha,” he sank and melted down, and wasn’t able to stay still.

an3.127:1.4.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma sappi vā telaṃ vā vālukāya āsittaṃ osīdatimeva saṃsīdatimeva, na saṇṭhāti;
an3.127:1.4.eng: It’s like when ghee or oil is poured on sand, it sinks and melts down, and can’t remain stable.

an3.127:1.6.pli: “bhagavato purato ṭhassāmī”ti osīdatimeva saṃsīdatimeva, na sakkoti saṇṭhātuṃ.

an3.127:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā hatthakaṃ devaputtaṃ etadavoca:
an3.127:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Hatthaka,

an3.127:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti, kho hatthako devaputto bhagavato paṭissutvā oḷārikaṃ attabhāvaṃ abhinimminitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
an3.127:2.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Hatthaka. He manifested a solid incarnation, bowed to the Buddha, and stood to one side.

an3.127:2.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho hatthakaṃ devaputtaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

an3.127:3.1.pli: “Ye te, hatthaka, dhammā pubbe manussabhūtassa pavattino ahesuṃ, api nu te te dhammā etarahi pavattino”ti?
an3.127:3.1.eng: “Hatthaka, I wonder whether you still promulgate now the teachings that you promulgated when you were a human being?”

an3.127:3.2.pli: “Ye ca me, bhante, dhammā pubbe manussabhūtassa pavattino ahesuṃ, te ca me dhammā etarahi pavattino;
an3.127:3.2.eng: “I still promulgate the teachings that I promulgated as a human being.

an3.127:3.3.pli: ye ca me, bhante, dhammā pubbe manussabhūtassa nappavattino ahesuṃ, te ca me dhammā etarahi pavattino.
an3.127:3.3.eng: And I also promulgate teachings that I didn’t promulgate as a human being.

an3.127:3.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, bhagavā etarahi ākiṇṇo viharati bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi rājūhi rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi;
an3.127:3.4.eng: Just as the Buddha these days lives crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their chief ministers, and monastics of other religions and their disciples,

an3.127:3.5.pli: evamevaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, ākiṇṇo viharāmi devaputtehi.
an3.127:3.5.eng: so I live crowded by the godlings.

an3.127:3.6.pli: Dūratopi, bhante, devaputtā āgacchanti hatthakassa devaputtassa santike ‘dhammaṃ sossāmā’ti.
an3.127:3.6.eng: The godlings come from far away, thinking, ‘We’ll hear the teaching in the presence of Hatthaka.’

an3.127:3.7.pli: Tiṇṇāhaṃ, bhante, dhammānaṃ atitto appaṭivāno kālaṅkato.
an3.127:3.7.eng: Sir, I passed away without getting enough of three things.

an3.127:3.9.pli: Bhagavato ahaṃ, bhante, dassanassa atitto appaṭivāno kālaṅkato;

an3.127:3.11.pli: saṅghassāhaṃ, bhante, upaṭṭhānassa atitto appaṭivāno kālaṅkato.

an3.127:3.12.pli: Imesaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ atitto appaṭivāno kālaṅkatoti.
an3.127:3.12.eng: I passed away without getting enough of these three things.

an3.127:5.2.eng: loving to hear the true teaching,

an3.127:5.3.eng: Hatthaka has gone to the Aviha realm

an3.127:5.4.eng: without getting enough of these three things.”

an3.128:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
an3.128:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.

an3.128:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya bārāṇasiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
an3.128:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Varanasi for alms.

an3.128:1.3.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā goyogapilakkhasmiṃ piṇḍāya caramāno aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ rittassādaṃ bāhirassādaṃ muṭṭhassatiṃ asampajānaṃ asamāhitaṃ vibbhantacittaṃ pākatindriyaṃ.
an3.128:1.3.eng: While the Buddha was walking for alms near the cow-hitching place at the wavy leaf fig, he saw a disgruntled monk who was looking for pleasure in external things, unmindful, without situational awareness or immersion, with straying mind and undisciplined faculties.

an3.128:2.2.pli: Taṃ vata, bhikkhu, kaṭuviyakataṃ attānaṃ āmagandhena avassutaṃ makkhikā nānupatissanti nānvāssavissantīti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”ti.
an3.128:2.2.eng: If you’re bitter, festering with putrefaction, flies will, without a doubt, plague and infest you.”

an3.128:2.3.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu bhagavatā iminā ovādena ovadito saṃvegamāpādi.
an3.128:2.3.eng: Hearing this advice of the Buddha, that monk was struck with a sense of urgency.

an3.128:2.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto bhikkhū āmantesi:
an3.128:2.4.eng: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, the Buddha told the mendicants what had happened. …

an3.128:3.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya bārāṇasiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ.

an3.128:3.2.pli: Addasaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, goyogapilakkhasmiṃ piṇḍāya caramāno aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ rittassādaṃ bāhirassādaṃ muṭṭhassatiṃ asampajānaṃ asamāhitaṃ vibbhantacittaṃ pākatindriyaṃ.

an3.128:4.2.pli: Taṃ vata bhikkhu kaṭuviyakataṃ attānaṃ āmagandhena avassutaṃ makkhikā nānupatissanti nānvāssavissantīti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī’ti.

an3.128:4.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, so bhikkhu mayā iminā ovādena ovadito saṃvegamāpādī”ti.

an3.128:4.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.128:4.4.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha:

an3.128:5.3.eng: and bad, unskillful thoughts are the flies.

an3.128:5.4.pli: Taṃ vata, bhikkhu, kaṭuviyakataṃ attānaṃ āmagandhena avassutaṃ makkhikā nānupatissanti nānvāssavissantīti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatīti.
an3.128:5.4.eng: If you’re bitter, festering with putrefaction, flies will, without a doubt, plague and infest you.

an3.128:6.1.eng: When your eyes and ears are unguarded,

an3.128:6.2.eng: and you’re not restrained in your sense faculties,

an3.128:8.2.eng: if they don’t find serenity in themselves,

an3.128:9.3.eng: they, being peaceful, sleep at ease,

an3.128:9.4.eng: since they’ve got rid of the flies.”

an3.129:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā anuruddho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.129:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Anuruddha went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an3.129:1.2.pli: “idhāhaṃ, bhante, dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena yebhuyyena passāmi mātugāmaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjamānaṃ.
an3.129:1.2.eng: “Sometimes, sir, with my clairvoyance that’s purified and superhuman, I see that ladies—when their body breaks up, after death—are mostly reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an3.129:1.3.pli: Katihi nu kho, bhante, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjatī”ti?
an3.129:1.3.eng: How many qualities do ladies have so that they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell?”

an3.129:2.1.pli: “Tīhi kho, anuruddha, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an3.129:2.1.eng: “When ladies have three qualities, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an3.129:2.3.pli: Idha, anuruddha, mātugāmo pubbaṇhasamayaṃ maccheramalapariyuṭṭhitena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, majjhanhikasamayaṃ issāpariyuṭṭhitena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati, sāyanhasamayaṃ kāmarāgapariyuṭṭhitena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati.
an3.129:2.3.eng: A lady lives at home with a heart full of the stain of stinginess in the morning, jealousy at midday, and sexual desire in the evening.

an3.129:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, anuruddha, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjatī”ti.
an3.129:2.4.eng: When ladies possess these three qualities, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.”
